social_posts.post_text:
Having residencies without requirements to “do something,” always leave me room to want to DO SOMETHING. When I was selected to be @longmeadowartresidency’s inaugural artist-in-residence, I knew exactly what I wanted to do and I’m happy to report that I was successful at accomplishing all of those things.   
  
As I get back to pondering MLK’s messages, efforts, life and sacrifice and my place in the contribution to those DREAMS STILL DIFFERED, I’ll leave you images and video from one of several installations I put together during my four months in the Berkshires of Massachusetts and a note I sent to founders Jennifer and David Feldman on my way home from the “artist’s home away from home” they built at one of their favorite places to be:   
  
  
“I was inspired up until the last minute of being here which means that the residency did its job! and by last minute, I mean I woke up early on the last day and finished a painting.   
  
During my time I returned to brush paintings. I expanded my assemblage vocabulary. I made wood, paper and canvas sculptures. I turned the residency house into an installation. I composed a few new songs upstairs in the loft on my keyboard. I opened up the home for others and made it a place they could feel loved. I made friends that I’ll have for a lifetime, including you (Jennifer & David). I ran virtual and in person tours. I got great sleep and stayed up late. I laughed and cried. I got through losses back home. I felt LIFE and LOVE all around me. and I did these things because LMAR gave me the time, space and resource to do what I set my mind and heart to do.”   
  
To learn more about the program, follow the Long Meadow Art Residency on Instagram and visit www.longmeadowartresidency.com 
 
Installation Photos by @la.vonte

This Thursday I’ll be exhibiting “The Cost of Freedom” and “Ponder The Price of FREE,” both made during my four month @longmeadowartresidency in the Berkshires of Massachusetts.   
  
The works will appear in @superpositiongallery’s “A Love Letter To LA,” group exhibition curated by @stormascher at @phillipsauction in Los Angeles.   
  
If you’ll be on the West Coast and would like to join me for the opening reception, please send an rsvp to assist@superpositiongallery.com or use the Eventbrite link:   
  
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/516779008927  
  
I’ll be there and I’m looking forward to seeing you!   
  
Opening Reception   
Thursday January 19th 5-8PM  
at  
PHILLIPS   
9041 Nemo Street   
West Hollywood, California 90069

It’s been such a WILD RIDE but it’s not over just yet. Today and tomorrow are the last days to see “A Love Letter To LA,” our group exhibition curated by @stormascher for @superpositiongallery at the new @phillipsauction space in Los Angeles. 
 
Thank you to everyone that’s showed up and showed LOVE so far. Go back, bring a friend. And if you haven’t gone yet, swing by with a friend.  
 
Don’t miss this one!  
 
“A Love Letter to LA”  
FINAL viewing days  
February 2nd & February 3rd  
10AM - 5PM 
at PHILLIPS  
9041 Nemo Street, West Hollywood.  
 
—  
 
Artwork (In Order Of Appearance)  
 
Ponder The Price of FREE, 2022 
Acrylic, Oil Stick, Wax Crayon, My Grandmother’s Statue, Paper, Pennies, Rescued Firewood, Nails, Wood & Chain  
12in x 9in (Paper), 5.5in x 16.4in (Wood Shelf), 20.5in x 9.5in x 7in (Firewood & Stick) 
 
The Cost Of FREEDOM, 2022 
Acrylic, Rice, Rope & Pennies on Wood Canvas 36in x 24in

“Memorabilia,” is another one of the many works I made during my four months in the Berkshires of Massachusetts at the @longmeadowartresidency.  
 
During my time I returned to brush paintings. I expanded my assemblage vocabulary. I made wood, paper and canvas sculptures. I turned the residency house into an installation. I composed a few new songs upstairs in the loft on my keyboard. I opened up the home for others and made it a place they could feel loved. I ran virtual and in person tours. I got great sleep and stayed up late. I laughed and cried. I got through losses back home. I felt LIFE and LOVE all around me. And I did these things because LMAR gave me the time, space and resource to do what I set my mind and heart to do. 
 
Thank you Jennifer, David and the rest of the LMAR family.  
 
To learn more about the program, follow the Long Meadow Art Residency on Instagram and visit www.longmeadowartresidency.com  
 
— Artwork —  
 
Memorabilia, 2022 
Rice, Rope, Pennies, Boxing Gloves & Eagle Sculpture on Wood Canvas  
60in x 48in

They say that all good things must come to an end but what I’m starting to see is that good things often bring on new BEGINNINGS!! It’s been such a great run with @katesferriprojects & all of my fellow artists in the “Dark Matter” group exhibition, curated by @stylecurator. And we couldn’t have done it without the support of everyone that came to our opening and throughout the show so thanks to each of you as well.  
 
Please make your way to the show either for the first time or go back again with a friend this Thursday, Friday or Saturday.  
 
And if you’d like to catch me, I’ll be there on Saturday from 5-6PM.  
 
“Dark Matter” Group Exhibition  
Kates-Ferri Projects  
561 Grand Street, NYC 
Thursday - Saturday  
February 9th - 11th  
12-6PM 
OR BY APPOINTMENT  
 
Exhibiting Artists:  
@kevinclaiborne @turiyaaaaaaaa @nnoromsamuel @iamjamelrobinson @misstheda @rudyshepherd @jairo_sosa_ @roscoebthicke  
 
— Artwork —  
 
A Blues In Rice Minor, 2022 
Acrylic, Oil Stick & Rice on Canvas 
36in x 24in 
 
Knot Quite FREE, 2022 
Acrylic, Wax Crayon & Rice on Wood Canvas  
36in x 24in

Detail: Jamel Robinson. If It Is Up To Me: A Song For Sam Gilliam, 2022.  
 
Oil Stick, acrylic, 8 pieces of 12in x 9in watercolor paper, vase, boxing gloves, nails, chain, and dried lavender on 60in x 48in canvas.   
  
  
I am super excited to unveil my new abstract assemblage installation, If It Is Up To Me: A Song For Sam Gilliam, included in “IMPULSE OF AN ERA" - a group exhibition curated by Ché Morales in partnership with Albertz Benda Gallery.  
  
Made shortly after the passing of the legendary abstract painter Sam Gilliam, this piece is an homage to the spirit of his mastery over technique and color and informed my practice of using assemblage to continue conversations around the historical and present trauma of the Black experience in America.   
  
IMPULSE OF AN ERA  
Curated by Ché Morales  
  
Albertz Benda Gallery  
515 West 26th Street  
New York, NY, 10001  
  
On view   
March 23 - April 22, 2023

BIG THANK YOU to everyone who made it out to the opening of “IMPULSE OF AN ERA,” our group exhibition curated by @chemorales in partnership with @albertzbenda Gallery.    And thank you to my assistant and talented brother @La.Vonte for his incredible film and photo work with our SONY A7IV.   
  
The exhibition will be on view through April 22nd so if you haven’t already, please go and check out the show and my new abstract assemblage installation “If It Is Up To Me: A Song For Sam Gilliam.”   
  
Made shortly after the passing of the legendary abstract painter Sam Gilliam, the piece is an homage to the spirit of his mastery over technique and color and informed my practice of using assemblage to continue conversations around the historical and present trauma of the Black experience in America.

Loving @adam.reichphotography’s photos of my new abstract assemblage installation “If It Is Up To Me: A Song For Sam Gilliam” from IMPULSE OF AN ERA, a group exhibition curated by Ché Morales in partnership with Albertz Benda Gallery. 
 
Made shortly after the passing of the legendary abstract painter Sam Gilliam, the piece is an homage to the spirit of his mastery over technique and color and informed my practice of using assemblage to continue conversations around the historical and present trauma of the Black experience in America.      
 
Swipe right to see some video I took of the piece during our opening as well as a short I shot on iPhone, edited and composed the score for of some of it being made in the studio.  
 
The exhibition will be on view through April 22nd so if you haven’t already, please go and check out!

IMPULSE OF AN ERA - our group exhibition curated by @chemorales in partnership with @albertzbenda Gallery is on view now through April 22nd, 2023.    
   
GO SEE IT and GO SEE IT AGAIN!! 🖼️  
   
And thank you to everyone who’s already seen the show thus far; I’m glad to hear that so many of you are connecting to my new abstract assemblage installation “If It Is Up To Me: A Song For Sam Gilliam.”       
      
Made shortly after the passing of the legendary abstract painter Sam Gilliam, the piece is an homage to the spirit of his mastery over technique and color and informed my practice of using assemblage to continue conversations around the historical and present trauma of the Black experience in America.

A little social media wellness check to let you know that all is well with my soul and I’ll be back with updates on group and solo exhibitions very soon. In the meantime, here’s some video and stills of just a few things happening in the studio.    
   
And as always; a huge THANK YOU to my overall right hand man, youngest sibling and the real boss of operations here at  #HarlemRoyaltyStudios @la.vonte, whose help really allows me to live out my long standing mantra: #AlwaysBeCreating. I’m even more excited to talk about what he’s up to creatively so stay extra tuned in for those announcements this Fall.    
   
Until next time…

THIS SUNDAY September 3rd is your last chance to see “Order / Reorder: Experiments with Collections” at HRM co-curated by @lvprosewriter & @bentleybrown___ and featuring works by me and many, many more.   
 
It was such a pleasure to be a part of this show with so many incredible artists and with some incredible mid-show transitions. KUDOS once again to the whole FAM!  
  
  
About the show:   
  
Order / Reorder is co-curated by Laura Vookles, Chair, HRM Curatorial Department, and Bentley Brown, Adjunct Professor of Art History at Fordham University and PhD Fellow, NYU Institute of Fine Arts.  
  
Several works in this exhibition are generously lent by @joslynartmuseum, Omaha, as part of the @artbridgesfoundation’s Collection Loan Partnership.  
  
Order / Reorder: Experiments with Collections is made possible by generous support from the New York State Senate and Majority Leader @andreastewartcousins

A few things I love in this world: creating, working with my youngest brother and sharing my life with good people. During my inaugural @longmeadowartresidency I got to do all these things.   
  
Here’s some footage I shot and @la.vonte edited that captures both my return to brush painting after a four year hiatus and one of the many open studio experiences he and I put together to unveil this twenty five piece installation that came out of my getting back into the practice.   
  
Thank you @jherman6130, David and the LMAR board for giving me time, resource and space to grow and expand and thank you @t.moore212, @lexi.in.the.city, @michaelgonzalesisasian and @a.a.lyne for making the trip up.

Have to give my right hand man, studio manager, film and design collaborator extraordinaire and youngest sibling @la.vonte some IG grid real estate to say HAPPY 27th BIRTHDAY!!  
 
Jesus loves you. Our family loves you. All my friends and colleagues love you. I love you.  
 
Thank you for helping me to build my vision and our legacy and for being an example of what it looks like to be a young Man of God.  
 
Keep being excellent. Keep shining. And definitely keep showing up to work on time so you can keep your job! LOL!  
 
Happy Birthday, baby bro!!

I am excited to announce my upcoming solo exhibition “The Eagle Flies Free, But Why Not Me?” at @mainstreetgallery495 in Catskill, New York with renowned curator-now-gallery-owner Michael Mosby, primarily featuring works made during my recent @longmeadowartresidency in the Berkshires of Massachusetts.  
 
Artist Statement:  
 
“I want people, primarily the youth, to ask why I’m using sand, rice, rope, pennies, nails, chains, and wood in the work so that, socially, we’re forced to address the truth regarding historical issues of race inequality that may have changed in shape, but are still the pulse of our country today.” - Jamel Robinson 
 
* Swipe Left For Press Release And Flyer * 
 
Opening Reception  
Saturday November 11th  
3-6PM  
Gallery 495 
495 MAIN STREET  
CATSKILL, New York 12534 
 
The Eagle Flies Free, But Why Not Me?  
On view:  
November 11th - January 13th, 2024

also by appointment

 “The Eagle Flies Free, But Why Not Me?” 2022

text_entities.entity: the eagle flies free but why not me

social_posts.post_text:
I start to forget of how many years Hannah and I have known and championed one another but I will never forget our 2019 collaboration on my project, ELLA, a namesake performance dedicated to my now late Grandmother. And now I won’t ever forget when she asked me to join the @cullenandthem Board of Directors and design the 2023 +Award for our annual Gala, honoring Slobodan Randjelović.
 
If you don’t already know, cullen+them is an intergenerational performing arts non profit dedicated to creating socially-conscious work and building empathetic community and @slonyc is a photographer, architect, philanthropist and major supporter of the arts. 
 
Like every other year, the Gala proved itself to be a magical evening. I can’t wait for you all to see what we get up to next. Until then..  
 
A few photos of my FIRST award design and “some” of the FAM!

Installation view and detail of “Piecemeal,” 2023 and “Can’t Fight For My FREE,” 2022.

Please join me, @alteroncegumby and @mitchelltm87 TOMORROW, Saturday December 16th, at 1PM for Material and Storytelling, a panel discussion of my solo exhibition “The Eagle Flies Free, But Why Not Me?” at @mainstreetgallery495 moderated by Jade Warwick.   
  
To RSVP for our in person talk, email  admin@mainstreetgallery495.com

Thank you for my life and thank you for living yours unapologetically so that I’d have a model for how to live mine. Thank you for never giving up and teaching me that it wasn’t ever going to be an option. And thank you for loving me unconditionally. Thank you for being you.  
 
Happy Birthday Mom. I love you.

Had such a great panel discussion a few weekends ago with my brother Alteronce Gumby thanks to some amazing questions by our moderator Jade Warwick. ⁣
⁣
Swipe ➡️ for some snippets and go to the @mainstreetgallery495 website to watch our discussion, “Material and Storytelling” in full. ⁣
⁣
And for those of you still planning your trips up to the exhibition, more updates about programming are forthcoming but know that I’ll be at the gallery January 6th, 7th and, of course, for the closing reception January 13th. ⁣
⁣

text_entities.entity: i walked the longest mile to get to nowhere still

social_posts.post_text:
“I want people, primarily the youth, to ask why I’m using sand, rice, rope, pennies, nails, chains, and wood in the work so that, socially, we’re forced to address the truth regarding historical issues of race inequality that may have changed in shape, but are still the pulse of our country today.”  - Jamel Robinson
 
Please join me on Saturday January 13th from 12PM - 6PM for the closing reception of my exhibition “The Eagle Flies Free, But Why Not Me?”  
 
I will be at the gallery for the exhibit’s final hours and will recite my poem HOME at 6PM to close the show.  
 
I look forward to seeing you!!  
 ⁣ 
Gallery 495   ⁣ 
495 MAIN STREET    ⁣ 
CATSKILL, New York 12414⁣

Timelapse video of our exhibition & photo of me and my brother Michael Mosby along with a public note of thanks:   
  
Dear Mike,  
  
I’m extremely proud to have partnered with you to show what I regard as one of my most important bodies of work. It has been a pleasure taking ground alongside you, my fellow HARLEM native. I’m excited to see where we go from here.   
  
Love you!!  Keep SHINING your LIGHT!!   
  
Please join us on Saturday January 13th from 12PM - 6PM for the closing reception of my exhibition “The Eagle Flies Free, But Why Not Me?”   
  
I will be at the gallery for the exhibit’s final hours and will recite my poem HOME at 6PM to close the show.   
  
I look forward to seeing you!!   
 ⁣  
Gallery 495   ⁣  
495 MAIN STREET    ⁣  
CATSKILL, New York 12414⁣

My exhibition “The Eagle Flies Free, But Why Not Me?” was on view from November 11th, 2023 through January 13th, 2024 at Gallery 495 in Catskill, New York.  
 
It was a labor of love and I thank every leg of the team that played a part in bringing this vision to life and I thank each of every one of you who carved out the time to come through and support and I thank all of you who lent your support virtually.  
 
It takes a village and I’m glad I’ve got a strong one surrounding me.  
 
From Sugar Hill to Catskill…  
 
I LOVE YOU.
